author: sky.cactus
content: <@543900561460822016> Imagine someone submits a transaction on block `n`, and then the fork is on block `n+1`, and then the transaction is mined on `n+2`.

author: sky.cactus
content: They'll get a transaction hash on block `n`, but then on block `n+1` all of the transactions will be reformed into new transaction types, which means new hashes.  Anyone who is doing `eth_getTransactionReceipt` using the hash they got back when they submitted their transaction will forever get `null` (in the na√Øve implementation).

content: I thought type 0 txs would hash the same as legacy txs?

author: lightclient
content: So the hash at n and n+2 are equal. At the fork block a new tx is allowed, type 1 which has a new hash scheme

author: sky.cactus
content: The signature would be the same, but the EIP doesn't currently talk about the hash.

author: sky.cactus
content: Long term, my preference would be that the hashes for *all* transaction types is the same, which is hash of the 2718 transaction (which would include the wrapped bytes).

author: sky.cactus
content: I dislike the idea of being stuck with two mechanisms for hashing transactions in all clients forever just because of a transient problem that dapps may face during the transition.

author: timbeiko
content:
<@!301186049323958275> / <@!191998356678115328>eybody-in-1559 üòÖ  here's a short update on where things are at for 1559 and what I see as potential next steps: 

- **Implementation**: Besu and Geth (via Vulcanize's work) both have a "99% done" 1559 implementation. A few tweaks here and there, but in short both are able to create, gossip and process 1559-style blocks and talk to each other ( <@!574864862338088960> ran a private geth <> besu network processing 1559 blocks a few weeks ago: https://twitter.com/PegaSysEng/status/1259919084445204482). IIRC, the geth implementation still uses fixed block sizes and besu has them removed already. As far as I'm aware, no "core dev" team aside from Besu is actively working on 1559. Geth isn't, Open Ethereum I don't know and Nethermind were starting to dig into it. 

Next steps for implementation IMO are to try and set up a small test network with 20M gas block to see what happens. Hopefully it gives _some_ indication that we can process those types of blocks without things falling over. We also have a call today to discuss how the escalator fits in to all of this, but given the feedback on the last call, I personally would rather not implement a change to 1559 until we have more analysis. If 1559 works at 20M gas, then so will 1559+escalator.

author: timbeiko
content: - **Reseach**: Here, what we have so far are <@!486501030046203915>'s analyses (in the ethereum/rig repo), <@!528251935829262351>'s recent piece on the escalator and.... that's about it. Barnabe will begin working on more advanced simulations, and I think we should pursue a formal mechanism design analysis to help inform what we do about 1559 vs. escalator vs. (maybe) typed transactions. This will likely take a few months, but IMO if the result is "1559+escalator is the best!", it's only a few weeks of engineering effort to update the implementations accordingly (and anyways only for Besu + Vulcanize given other clients won't have started).

author: timbeiko
content: If people have feedback on this, or if there's anything it seems like I'm missing, please let me know.

author: timbeiko
content: My aim is also to share regular updates on the AllCoreDevs call to try and catch any concern early (i.e. like Nick Johnson's) so we proactively address them vs. spend 6 months with a "done" EIP that we're trying to push on the calls.

content: Imagine if 75% of miners all set min tip to 2 nanoeth.  25% of miners set min tip to 1 nanoeth (which is just over opportunity cost of uncling).  Users who are willing to wait ~4 blocks would pay 1 nanoeth, and those 25% of miners would always have big blocks (meaning, over half full in 1559).  Those 75% of miners would (on average) have *less than half full blocks*, but at a higher fee per gas.

author: sky.cactus
content: While I agree with you and it is true that it is *possible* that raising min-tip as a group could be profitable, it depends on an unknown of end-user function for inclusion speed demands.

author: sky.cactus
content: For an extreme example, if 99% of users are willing to pay 100 nanoeth more for inclusion 1 block sooner, then if 25% of miners set their min tip to 101 nanoeth they'll turn a profit.

author: sky.cactus
content: What I am very dubious about is whether the demand for improving inclusion speed is high enough.

author: sky.cactus
content: As for "can users push back against miners doing this", the answer is yes.  If there is a miner cabal that are all setting min tip to 10 nanoeth, you can set your tip to 9.9 nanoeth.  This will heavily reward anyone who defects from the cabal, and make it very profitable to be a defector.

author: sky.cactus
content: If a new cabal forms at 9.9 nanoeth, users can start offering tips of 9.8 nanoeth.

author: sky.cactus
content: Repeat until the tips are back down.

author: sky.cactus
content: Even if we start in an unhealthy state, it isn't a stable equilibrium as it is can be profitable to defect, if users participate in breaking up the cabal.

author: sky.cactus
content: Even if users don't break up the cabal, I don't *personally* believe that the demand for inclusion speed is high enough for the cabal to be stable.  For most of my transactions, I don't mind waiting a few extra blocks for inclusion if it means getting half-off on fees.  Especially for larger (gas) transactions.
